TITLE: 'It's frustrating and stressful.' 40 million people are in the dark about whether or not student loan payments will resume
SUMMARY: Two weeks before federal student loan payments are set to resume, the Biden administration hasn't said whether or not there will be another extension.

TITLE: Here are the top 10 colleges for financial aid. Ruling out pricey schools is a 'tragically flawed' strategy, says Princeton Review editor
SUMMARY: The top colleges for financial aid are private and have sky-high sticker prices, yet their very generous aid packages make them surprisingly affordable.

TITLE: Worried you're mismanaging your money? Give yourself a financial checkup in 7 simple steps
SUMMARY: Inflation or no inflation, a financial checkup is always a good idea. Here are seven steps to take to assess your money health now.

TITLE: The Inflation Reduction Act caps costs for Medicare patients on insulin. Where the push for broader relief stands
SUMMARY: The Inflation Reduction Act will limit insulin co-pays for Medicare patients to $35 per month. Where efforts to provide similar relief to other patients stand.

TITLE: Financing a new car? Here's how much you can save thanks to a good or excellent credit score
SUMMARY: For a five-year, new-car loan of $45,000, buyers with excellent credit scores generally can save thousands of dollars by qualifying for lower interest rates.

TITLE: IRS interest rates jump to 6% on Oct. 1. Here’s how much money you’ll get for a missing refund
SUMMARY: If you’re still waiting on a tax refund, you may be earning interest on your unpaid balance, and the rate jumps to 6% on Oct. 1, according to the IRS.

TITLE: Biden administration cancels $3.9 billion in student debt for 208,000 borrowers defrauded by  ITT Tech
SUMMARY: The U.S. Department of Education announced Tuesday that it would cancel the student loans for 208,000 borrowers who attended ITT Technical Institute.

TITLE:
Op-ed: America's colleges must get into the customer service game because they have failed 
to meet the needs of all students
SUMMARY: College administrators should take a page out of corporate America's playbook and make customer service a priority. Our students, after all, are our customers.

TITLE: 3 tips for paying down your credit card balances as interest rates jump, according to a debt counselor
SUMMARY: Americans are struggling to keep up with day-to-day expenses and increasingly relying on credit cards just as APRs head to a record high.

TITLE: House Democrats call for action on Social Security reform. What that could mean for your benefits
SUMMARY: Democrats are seeking to bring a bill to enhance Social Security benefits up for a vote on the House floor this fall. Here's what it includes.

TITLE: Drivers are paying an average $702 monthly for new cars: Here's why that record high was 'inevitable,' says analyst
SUMMARY: With interest rates rising and the average transaction price on a new car just below $46,000, consumers may want to explore ways to keep costs down.

TITLE: Investors flock to green energy funds as Congress passes climate bill. What to know as assets reach ‘new territory’
SUMMARY: There's been a surge of interest in green energy funds as Congress allocates $369 billion for climate change funding. Here's what investors need to know.

TITLE: 75% of families don’t know a key date to get financial aid for college
SUMMARY: To get financial assistance for college, students must file a Free Application for Federal Student Aid.

TITLE: If you're facing bankruptcy, here's what experts say to do before, during and after you file
SUMMARY: With inflation rising and government aid waning, personal bankruptcies may start to climb again soon. If you're facing bankruptcy, here's advice from experts.

TITLE: Consumers may qualify for up to $10,000 — or more — in climate tax breaks and rebates in the Inflation Reduction Act
SUMMARY: The Inflation Reduction Act offers financial incentives in the form of consumer rebates and tax credits to help the U.S. reduce its greenhouse gas emissions.

TITLE: Changes are coming to improve student loan forgiveness for borrowers in public service
SUMMARY: Borrowers pursuing public service loan forgiveness could see a number of new, friendlier terms in coming months.

TITLE: U.S. workers lost about $28 billion in wages during Covid-19 due to lack of access to paid leave, report finds
SUMMARY: The U.S. is one of the few countries without a national paid leave program. Gaps in worker access to paid leave were exposed during Covid-19, a report finds.

TITLE: Investors are piling into high-yield bonds. What to know before adding 'junk' to your portfolio
SUMMARY: With a recent influx of money pouring into high-yield bonds, financial experts urge caution before piling in. Here's what investors need to know.

TITLE: 5.2% of job ads offer a signing bonus — but 8 fields have the most. Here's how workers can negotiate one
SUMMARY: Employers are offering signing bonuses at a rate three times higher than pre-pandemic levels. Workers can use their leverage to sweeten the deal.

TITLE: 8.2 million people may soon get health insurance rebates up to an average $155 per person
SUMMARY: If you qualify for the rebate, you should either receive a check in the mail by Sept. 30 or a discount on your premium.

TITLE: 26% of job switchers regret joining the Great Resignation, survey finds: 'They’ve sobered up'
SUMMARY: Nearly 48 million Americans quit their jobs last year. Now, some are starting to have second thoughts.

TITLE: Addressing Social Security's funding woes will take political compromise, Biden nominee to advisory board says
SUMMARY: Andrew Biggs, who was nominated to the Social Security Advisory Board by President Joe Biden, weighs in on his thoughts on the future of the program.

TITLE: With inflation running at a 40-year high, 36% of U.S. adults tapped their savings to cover living expenses: Survey
SUMMARY: With inflation running at 40-year highs, 36% of adults in a new survey said they have had to turn to savings to cover their living expenses.

TITLE: State, local relief not in cards for residents of high-tax states as House assesses Inflation Reduction Act
SUMMARY: After fighting to repeal the SALT deduction limit, a group of House Democrats say they'll vote for the party's spending package without SALT reform.

TITLE: Back-to-school shopping takes 'a major financial toll' amid high inflation. Here's how to save on supplies for the fall
SUMMARY: Top tips to save on school supplies as back-to-school shopping takes a bigger bite of the budget this year.

TITLE: Airfares, hotel rates and rental car prices fell in July. Here’s how you can score a good deal
SUMMARY: The price for major components of vacation travel have declined for two consecutive months, according to the U.S. Department of Labor's Consumer Price Index.

TITLE: A phantom debt collection scam duped consumers out of more than $1 million. Here are 5 ways you can avoid falling victim
SUMMARY: If you receive a surprise call or letter about unpaid debts of which you are not aware, don't panic. Take these steps first.

TITLE: Retirees on Social Security could see monthly benefit rise an average of $159 in 2023 due to inflation, estimate finds
SUMMARY: High inflation points to a possible 9.6% Social Security cost-of-living adjustment in 2023, according to a new estimate based on data released on Wednesday.

TITLE: Gas is cheaper but groceries are not: How to save as food inflation jumps at the fastest pace since 1979
SUMMARY: Food costs climbed 1.1% in July, bringing the year-over-year gain to 10.9%, according to the latest Consumer Price Index figures.

TITLE: Buying a car and want to go electric? Inflation Reduction Act extends $7,500 tax credit — but with price, income caps
SUMMARY: Single buyers of electric vehicles would need to have income of less than $150,000 to qualify for the credit, and luxury models would largely be ineligible.
